page.title: 06Harris Tweed.
page.content: Although this material is called 'Harris' tweed it is woven in most of the islands in the Outer Hebrides, mainly Lewis. When tweeds are sold they are stamped with the 'orb' mark, which means that the product is 100% pure new wool and hand-woven. were it not for this mark, the weaver would be out of business, as the same tweed, could be produced on a power loom, but being hand-woven it is more expensive to buy, and in turn entitles the weaver to a higher wage. An average tweed is thirty eight weavers yards long, a weavers yard is 8 feet so a tweed is 304 feet. The weft threads are called 'picks', and there is on average 18 picks to an inch of material.
